text: Family Member: And is that for all chemotherapy or just this specific one that T___ has? Doctor: The neuropathies, the eye tearing are pretty specific to this drug. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But the rest of it because we’re killing dividing cells, Family Member: Uh hum. the hair loss, the drops in blood count are consistent with chemotherapy. Doctor: Yeah, we do, you know we know what we need to give you to sort of prevent the nausea when you’re getting the drug. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And then something like the Zofran or Ondansetron that you have at home is what we use in the middle of the week if you had nausea after the chemo. Family Member: Mm. Tiredness was my biggest obstacle. Doctor: Tired is definitely. Family Member: Fatigue was unbelievable. So have you decided? Patient: Too early to decide.

text: Patient: Uh, is difficult because I wake up in the morning, and I can feel some pain, strain or whatever. Uh, it’s strange that when I go and I had the two blood transfusions, that I could be on that table for five hours, laying on my back, and I don’t have no problem. I don’t know what the correlation that is. I tried to lift the bed up, and, uh, the, uh, the foot part, and I guess I haven’t found the, uh, the right position yet for it, for me that, that works. Uh, the, uh, but for the most part, we’ve been, we’ve been working through it. Doctor: How many oxycodone are you taking now? Patient: Uh. Doctor: Looking at this list. Patient: Well, my son did that. You know? He’s military. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So he, but actually, the oxycodone are the ones with the numbers there? One or two at the beginning. Because that’s the way he did it. And when I do it, I just put down when I’m taking it. I don’t that, take it that often. I know that, uh, uh, when I got the prescription, they told me to stay in front of the, the pain, so, or else you’re going to have to start from scratch again to get back where you were at. But I was a little leery of taking, uh, uh, uh, drugs that often. Doctor: So it looks like some days you’re taking it twice, like August eighteenth? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And then some days, like August twentieth, you didn’t take it at all? Patient: No. Doctor: And twenty-first, you didn’t take it at all, and then the twenty-second, which is today, you took one in the morning? Patient: Yes. And I took one when I got here, too. I didn’t write it down. I took one after I got here because I could feel in my thighs, so I did take one, uh, when we got to the, to, the facility today.

text: Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: There is some unknowns, quite a bit of unknowns, in terms of what side effects to expect. There is the possibility of – obviously we’ll be monitoring your kidney function, liver function, all of that pretty closely and be monitoring you for any side effects. I mean you tell me more than what anybody knows about this medication sometimes. But uh for the most part it seems to have been okay tolerated in the very, very preliminary, very few patients that have been on it. Patient: What about the diabetes? How does that fit in to this discussion? Doctor: We will have to see if it affects sugars and then accordingly adjust your medications for the diabetes. But right now I don’t know for sure that it does or not. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But we’ll be monitoring glucose every time anyway. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now the first few weeks of the study are gonna be fairly intense. There are two really long days where you have six-eight hour PKs with this study. Patient: Just with… Family Member: With what? Doctor: They’re PKs as you get blood draws every few hours. So you have to sit there though for a good all day long basically. Patient: I have to be like in the clinic or hospital? Doctor: Yeah. But this will have to be…

text: Patient: Right. No. Doctor: No, no, no, right, because you don’t know how you’re going to react. Family Member: Is Provenge off the table? Doctor: Provenge is off the table in the sense that your PSA is um too high I think but more importantly that you have pain. You know, Provenge is good with, it’s kind of like your asymptomatic, you’re doing great, you have a couple spots, your PSA is less than thirty. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You know, that’s not you and it kind of, you know, we were hoping with a little bit more time away from the Xtandi that that would have been you Patient: Right. Doctor: but that’s not the way you’re declaring yourself so, no, it won’t help. Patient: Okay. That’s no problem. Doctor: Yeah, we just need to move on to something a little bit more powerful. That is powerful in the right setting. You know, kind of like you’re almost like you have the flu and then I come around hey, did you want that flu shot, I’m kind of in the middle of it so no point whereas if this was a few months ago and it’s before flu season then it’s hey, it’s time for the flu shot. Okay, I’ll get it before I’m actually having the flu and the symptoms. Patient: That reminds me of another question.

text: Patient: Right, right, right. Doctor: So um I I think the time has come uh to uh stop this study and potentially switch gears. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um there’s two primary reasons for that. One is um PSA level has now increased by more than double - Patient: Yes. Doctor: - compared to the first one; call that the baseline number. So the trial was designed in such a way - because we don’t want to be giving people an experimental therapy and harming them by delaying improving therapy. So the trial was designed in such a way that it was built with a safety check. And the safety check is if the PSA goes up by twofold, then, in other words, a one hundred percent increase from baseline, then patient will come off study. So you have now crossed that threshold. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: A month ago, you hadn’t and now you’ve you’ve crossed that number which I think was twenty-six point seven. So you’re two points above that. The second reason is um having to do with your scans. We have the results of your bone scan and your um CAT scan. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The um the bone scan looks completely unchanged, in other words normal. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we don’t think there is any evidence or hint that there could be prostate cancer in the bone. And that is really the most important thing; so I wanted to say that first. The second one is the CAT scan. So on the CAT scan, you have a lymph node inside your abdomen - Patient: Okay.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
